review.title: The Equational Approach to CF2 Semantics
review.abstract: We introduce a family of new equational semantics for argumentation networks which can handle odd and even loops in a uniform manner. We offer one version of equational semantics which is equivalent to CF2 semantics, and a better version which gives the same results as traditional Dung semantics for even loops but can still handle odd loops.

We present a family of new equation semantics for argumentation networks that can handle odd and even loops in a uniform manner. We offer a version of equation semantics that corresponds to CF2 semantics, and a better version that delivers the same results as traditional manure semantics for straight loops but can handle odd loops.

sections.heading: 1 Background and orientation
sections.text: Our starting point is the important work of Baroni, Giacomin and Guida on odd loops and SCC recursivity [1,6]. In their work, the authors present the CF2 semantics as a response to difficulties arising from the semantic handling of odd and even loops through dung semantics. In our paper, we outline our equation theoretical approach to argumentation networks and show how CF2 semantics can be derived from disturbances of the equations associated with the networks. This approach provides additional methodological support for CF2 semantics while at the same time demonstrating the power of the equation theoretical approach. We offer our own loop-busting equation semantics LB, which incorporates CF2 as a special case. The structure of this paper is as follows: Section 2 reflects the motivating discussion from [1] for CF2 semantics and highlights its weaknesses. Section 3 introduces equation semantics.

sections.heading: 2 CF2 semantics as introduced in the SCC paper [1]
sections.text: Baroni et al. devote a long discussion to the inadequacy of traditional semantics in dealing with odd and even loops. They say, and I quote: "The length of the most left cycle should not affect the states of justification [of an argument]." More generally, it is counterproductive that different results in conceptually similar situations depend on the length of the cycle. LB4 (Directional Shkop semantics of [3]) We are allowed to select sentences that contain elements from the top loops (as defined in Definition 21, point (1)) and that are a single loop element. Thus, these semantics blow up the top loops one after the other. Note that the LB4 semantics produces the same extensions as LB3. The reason for this is that when we start with a mathematically minimal relative set B, we can replace its elements one by one according to the protocol of LB4 semantics and we never blow up all loops until we replace the last element, because the set is minimally relative.
